air gun: a gun discharged by means of compressed air
bayonet: A bayonet is a long, sharp blade that can be fixed to the end of a rifle and used as a weapon.
bazooka: A bazooka is a long, tube-shaped gun that is held on the shoulder and fires rockets.
big bertha: any of three large German guns of World War I used to bombard Paris
blunderbuss: an obsolete short musket with large bore and flared muzzle, used to scatter shot at short range
bomb: A bomb is a device which explodes and damages or destroys a large area.
bowie knife: a stout hunting knife with a short hilt and a guard for the hand
cannon: A cannon is a large gun, usually on wheels, which used to be used in battles.
carbine: A carbine is a light automatic rifle.
crossbow: A crossbow is a weapon consisting of a small, powerful bow that is fixed across a piece of wood, and aimed like a gun.
depth charge: A depth charge is a type of bomb which explodes under water and which is used especially to destroy enemy submarines.
flame thrower: A flame-thrower is a gun that can send out a stream of burning liquid and that is used as a weapon or for clearing plants from an area of ground.
gatling gun: a hand-cranked automatic machine gun equipped with a rotating cluster of barrels that are fired in succession using brass cartridges
grenade launcher: A weapon that shoots grenades from a device.
gun: A gun is a weapon from which bullets or other things are fired.
halberd: a weapon consisting of a long shaft with an axe blade and a pick, topped by a spearhead: used in 15th- and 16th-century warfare
handgun: A handgun is a gun that you can hold, carry, and fire with one hand.
improvised explosive device: abbr IED a home-made explosive device designed to maim, harass, or kill
lance: If a boil on someone's body is lanced, a small cut is made in it so that the liquid inside comes out.
land mine: an explosive charge placed in the ground, usually detonated by stepping or driving on it
machine gun: A machine gun is a gun which fires a lot of bullets one after the other very quickly.
mine: Mine is the first person singular possessive pronoun. A speaker or writer uses mine to refer to something that belongs or relates to himself or herself.
mortar: A mortar is a big gun which fires missiles high into the air over a short distance.
musket: A musket was an early type of gun with a long barrel, which was used before rifles were invented.
nightstick: A nightstick is a short thick club that is carried by policemen in the United States.
onager: a Persian variety of the wild ass, Equus hemionus Compare kiang
pike: A pike is a large fish that lives in rivers and lakes and eats other fish.
pistol: A pistol is a small gun.
quarterstaff: a stout iron-tipped wooden staff about 6ft long, formerly used in England as a weapon
revolver: A revolver is a kind of hand gun. Its bullets are kept in a revolving cylinder in the gun.
rifle: A rifle is a gun with a long barrel.
rocket launcher: A rocket launcher is a device that can be carried by soldiers and used for firing rockets.
scimitar: A scimitar is a sword with a curved blade that was used in former times in some Eastern countries.
shotgun: A shotgun is a gun used for shooting birds and animals which fires a lot of small metal balls at one time.
sling: If you sling something somewhere, you throw it there carelessly.
spear: A spear is a weapon consisting of a long pole with a sharp metal point attached to the end.
stun gun: a device designed to immobilize an animal or person temporarily without inflicting serious injury
submachine gun: A sub-machine gun is a light portable type of machine gun.
sword: A sword is a weapon with a handle and a long sharp blade.
thermonuclear warhead: the warhead of a missile designed to deliver an atom bomb
torpedo: A torpedo is bomb that is shaped like a tube and that travels under water.
trebuchet: A medieval siege engine consisting of a large pivoting arm heavily weighted on one end. Considered to be the technological successor to the ...
